articles.headline: ‘It Was a Massacre’: How Security Forces Cracked Down in Southeastern Iran
articles.snippet: A New York Times analysis of witness testimony and videos reveals a bloody scene that unfolded last month in Zahedan during Friday Prayer, with mats as stretchers and bodies piled in cars.
articles.abstract: A New York Times analysis of witness testimony and videos reveals a bloody scene that unfolded last month in Zahedan during Friday Prayer, with mats as stretchers and bodies piled in cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the wounded tried to crawl away to escape the gunfire. Others bled to death on prayer mats as people tried to drag them to safety.
articles.byline: By Cora Engelbrecht, Nilo Tabrizy and Ishaan Jhaveri

articles.headline: In U.K. Fallout, Lessons for a World Facing Harsh Economic Realities
articles.snippet: The sharp policy U-turn by Liz Truss, Britain’s prime minister, reveals the perils of taking the wrong path in the fight against scalding inflation.
articles.abstract: The sharp policy U-turn by Liz Truss, Britain’s prime minister, reveals the perils of taking the wrong path in the fight against scalding inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government leaders in the West are struggling with rising inflation, slowing growth, and anxious electorates worried about winter and high energy bills. But Liz Truss, Britain’s prime minister, is the only one who devised an economic plan that unnerved financial markets, drew the ire of global leaders and the public and undermined her political standing.

articles.headline: Founder of Electric Truck Maker Is Convicted of Fraud
articles.snippet: Trevor Milton was accused of boasting about nonexistent technology to inflate the stock price of Nikola, a maker of electric trucks.
articles.abstract: Trevor Milton was accused of boasting about nonexistent technology to inflate the stock price of Nikola, a maker of electric trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury on Friday found Trevor Milton guilty of defrauding investors by lying about the supposed technical achievements of Nikola, the electric truck maker he founded.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Foments More Geopolitical Controversy With Ukraine Internet Dispute
articles.snippet: The world’s richest man, whose Starlink internet service is critical to the Ukrainian Army, said he could not “indefinitely” fund the system’s use in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The world’s richest man, whose Starlink internet service is critical to the Ukrainian Army, said he could not “indefinitely” fund the system’s use in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Russia invaded Ukraine, Elon Musk gave the Ukrainians a digital lifeline by providing them with the Starlink internet service operated by his rocket company, SpaceX.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Cassandra Vinograd and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Echoes of Latin American Racism Reverberate in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Disparaging remarks about Oaxacans from the Los Angeles City Council president shocked a city that prides itself on tolerance. But they highlighted a history of racism within the Latino community.
articles.abstract: Disparaging remarks about Oaxacans from the Los Angeles City Council president shocked a city that prides itself on tolerance. But they highlighted a history of racism within the Latino community.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ivan Vasquez arrived in Los Angeles in 1996, a teenager who had crossed the border to find work and improve the lot of his family in Mexico. As a newbie washing dishes in restaurants, the young man from the majority Indigenous state of Oaxaca was often called “Oaxaquita,” or Little Oaxacan, by other Mexicans because of his deep tan skin and diminutive stature.

articles.headline: What the $24.6 Billion Kroger-Albertsons Merger Could Mean for Groceries
articles.snippet: Two of the largest U.S. supermarket chains hope to join forces as inflation pushes food prices higher and as Amazon and Walmart become more powerful.
articles.abstract: Two of the largest U.S. supermarket chains hope to join forces as inflation pushes food prices higher and as Amazon and Walmart become more powerful.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grocery giant Kroger announced plans on Friday to acquire Albertsons in a $24.6 billion deal that could reshape the supermarket landscape in the United States. If it is approved by officials, the deal would unite two of the country’s largest supermarket chains to create a corporate behemoth that collectively generates $209 billion in revenue a year and operates nearly 5,000 stores.

articles.headline: The Student Loan Borrowers Who Keep Missing Out on Relief
articles.snippet: In a startling change, many in the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program may no longer be eligible for up to $20,000 in debt cancellation.
articles.abstract: In a startling change, many in the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program may no longer be eligible for up to $20,000 in debt cancellation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, with no notice or apology, the Education Department changed an important couple of sentences on its website. The result: A particular group of student loan borrowers woke up to discover that they had lost the option to get their debt canceled by five figures.

articles.headline: How One School Is Beating the Odds in Math, the Pandemic’s Hardest-Hit Subject
articles.snippet: Benjamin Franklin Elementary in Connecticut overhauled the way it taught — and the way it ran the classroom. Every minute counted.
articles.abstract: Benjamin Franklin Elementary in Connecticut overhauled the way it taught — and the way it ran the classroom. Every minute counted.
articles.lead_paragraph: MERIDEN, Conn. — It’s just after lunchtime, and Dori Montano’s fifth-grade math class is running on a firm schedule.

articles.headline: Peter Thiel, Major U.S. Political Donor, Is Said to Pursue Maltese Citizenship
articles.snippet: Obtaining citizenship in Malta would provide another passport for Mr. Thiel, who is one of the largest individual donors for the U.S. midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Obtaining citizenship in Malta would provide another passport for Mr. Thiel, who is one of the largest individual donors for the U.S. midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALLETTA, Malta — At the end of a narrow road, past crushed beer cans and the remnants of a chain-link fence, a weathered sandstone building overlooks the Mediterranean coast. The British tourist who answered the door of a third-floor apartment had no idea she was staying at the residence of one of the world’s richest men.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Justin Scheck

articles.headline: The Rent Revolution Is Coming
articles.snippet: For the 44 million households who rent a home or apartment in the U.S., inflation keeps pushing costs higher and higher. Anger is rising too. It could be a breaking point.
articles.abstract: For the 44 million households who rent a home or apartment in the U.S., inflation keeps pushing costs higher and higher. Anger is rising too. It could be a breaking point.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s a list of places you might imagine seeing an argument over housing policy. A city council meeting. A late-night zoning hearing. Maybe a ribbon-cutting to christen a new affordable housing complex.

articles.headline: Three Women of Bucha: Their Deaths and Lives
articles.snippet: New reporting illuminates the fortitude of three women — a former public servant, an animal lover, a grandmother — who were victims of Russian brutality.
articles.abstract: New reporting illuminates the fortitude of three women — a former public servant, an animal lover, a grandmother — who were victims of Russian brutality.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — One woman was badly beaten and shot through the eye. Another, held captive by Russian soldiers, was found in a cellar, shot in the head. An 81-year-old grandmother was discovered hanging in her garden, perhaps killed, perhaps driven to suicide.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

articles.headline: New Generation of Combat Vets, Eyeing House, Strike From the Right
articles.snippet: A class of political newcomers with remarkable military records is challenging old ideas about interventionism — and the assumption that electing veterans is a way to bring back bipartisanship.
articles.abstract: A class of political newcomers with remarkable military records is challenging old ideas about interventionism — and the assumption that electing veterans is a way to bring back bipartisanship.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2019, as the Defense Department’s bureaucracy seemed to be slow-walking then-President Donald J. Trump’s order to withdraw all U.S. forces from Syria, Joe Kent, a C.I.A. paramilitary officer, called his wife, Shannon, a Navy cryptologic technician who was still in Syria working against the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Democrats Spent $2 Trillion to Save the Economy. They Don’t Want to Talk About It.
articles.snippet: Polls show voters liked direct payments from President Biden’s 2021 economic rescue bill. But they have become fodder for Republican inflation attacks.
articles.abstract: Polls show voters liked direct payments from President Biden’s 2021 economic rescue bill. But they have become fodder for Republican inflation attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of a critical runoff campaign that would determine control of the Senate, the Rev. Raphael Warnock promised Georgia voters that, if elected, he would help President-elect Biden send checks to people digging out of the pandemic recession.

articles.headline: ‘Coffins Are Already Coming’: The Toll of Russia’s Chaotic Draft
articles.snippet: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
articles.abstract: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
articles.lead_paragraph: A half-dozen Russian soldiers talk about being shipped to an area of intense fighting in eastern Ukraine just 11 days after their mobilization. Asked about his shooting practice, a bearded conscript says, “Once. Three magazines.”

articles.headline: Strikes Hit Staging Ground for Troops in Russia’s Border Region
articles.snippet: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
articles.abstract: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Struggling on the battlefield in southern and eastern Ukraine, Russia felt war on its own territory on Sunday as more than a dozen explosions ripped through a Russian border region, and a series of blasts severely damaged the offices of Russia’s puppet government in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Democrats in Tight Races Turn to Jill Biden on the Campaign Trail
articles.snippet: Requests for the first lady, who is also the president’s most popular surrogate, are piling up ahead of the midterm elections. Her visits can deliver a morale boost and a fund-raising opportunity.
articles.abstract: Requests for the first lady, who is also the president’s most popular surrogate, are piling up ahead of the midterm elections. Her visits can deliver a morale boost and a fund-raising opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Jill Biden’s weekend included five flights, 11 events and three appearances with Democrats who all requested her help ahead of the midterm elections. There was also a spin class in there somewhere.

articles.headline: Iran’s Loyal Security Forces Protect Ruling System That Protesters Want to Topple
articles.snippet: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
articles.abstract: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The intensity of protests that have swept Iran over the past month, with calls to topple the Islamic Republic, have shaken the state. But in some ways, the country’s authoritarian clerical rulers have been preparing for this moment since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, which established a conservative theocracy that has held firm until today.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Republicans Gain Edge as Voters Worry About Economy, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
articles.abstract: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans enter the final weeks of the contest for control of Congress with a narrow but distinct advantage as the economy and inflation have surged as the dominant concerns, giving the party momentum to take back power from Democrats in next month’s midterm elections, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found.

articles.headline: Fencing Can Be Six-Figure Expensive, but It Wins in College Admissions
articles.snippet: How niche sports offer a pathway to the Ivy League and other elite schools.
articles.abstract: How niche sports offer a pathway to the Ivy League and other elite schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Supreme Court hearings on affirmative action.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Photographs by Desiree Rios

articles.headline: The Rise of a Conservative Radio Juggernaut
articles.snippet: Salem Media, which counts the conservative personalities Charlie Kirk and Sebastian Gorka among its radio hosts, has taken a pointed stance ahead of the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Salem Media, which counts the conservative personalities Charlie Kirk and Sebastian Gorka among its radio hosts, has taken a pointed stance ahead of the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent months, the conservative personalities Eric Metaxas, Sebastian Gorka and Charlie Kirk have used their nationally syndicated radio shows to discuss baseless claims of rigged voting machines, accuse election officials of corruption and espouse ballot fraud conspiracy theories.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: ‘Moving Backward’: In Xi’s China, Some See an Era of Total Control
articles.snippet: A decade ago, many prominent Chinese hoped that Xi Jinping would usher in openness and reform. Today, some of them believe he has created a totalitarian state.
articles.abstract: A decade ago, many prominent Chinese hoped that Xi Jinping would usher in openness and reform. Today, some of them believe he has created a totalitarian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Xi Jinping was preparing to take the helm of the Chinese Communist Party a decade ago, a great number of China’s political, business and intellectual elites were hopeful that he would make their country more open, just and prosperous.

articles.headline: In Xi’s China, the Business of Business Is State-Controlled
articles.snippet: The Chinese leader has increasingly demanded that businesses conform to the aims of the Communist Party, an agenda he doubled down on this week at an important political gathering.
articles.abstract: The Chinese leader has increasingly demanded that businesses conform to the aims of the Communist Party, an agenda he doubled down on this week at an important political gathering.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his decade as China’s leader, Xi Jinping regularly promoted the importance of opening up the economy even as he pushed the country sharply in the opposite direction. But as he laid out his ambitions at an important political meeting, he barely paid lip service to the notion.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Chang Che and Claire Fu

articles.headline: Kanye West to Buy Parler, Joining the Right-Wing Social Media Crowd
articles.snippet: The platform announced the deal days after Twitter and Instagram restricted the rapper and entrepreneur’s accounts for posting incendiary content.
articles.abstract: The platform announced the deal days after Twitter and Instagram restricted the rapper and entrepreneur’s accounts for posting incendiary content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kanye West, the rapper, fashion designer and firebrand increasingly known for divisive cultural and political commentary that has been called racist, appears set to become the owner of a social media service known for its right-wing audience.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: An Uptick in Elder Poverty: A Blip, or a Sign of Things to Come?
articles.snippet: Seniors didn’t fare as well through the pandemic as most. But longer-term trends aren’t moving in their favor, either.
articles.abstract: Seniors didn’t fare as well through the pandemic as most. But longer-term trends aren’t moving in their favor, either.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, more than a third of older Americans lived in poverty. With the aid of federal programs like Medicare to help the elderly, the situation improved significantly. But last year, the poverty rate for those 65 or older increased, even as it sank for everyone else.
articles.byline: By Lydia DePillis and Mike Belleme

articles.headline: Right-Wing Leaders Mobilize Corps of Election Activists
articles.snippet: Officials are prepared for aggressive challenges in midterm elections. “We’re going to adjudicate every battle,” Stephen K. Bannon said.
articles.abstract: Officials are prepared for aggressive challenges in midterm elections. “We’re going to adjudicate every battle,” Stephen K. Bannon said.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the eve of a primary runoff election in June, a Republican candidate for secretary of state of South Carolina sent out a message to his supporters.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
